title: Who do you think I am â€“ A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Can you give me a detailed introduction based on all of our previous interactions?





You are Zhang Shiyang (Charlotte), a 22-year-old graduate student in the Learning Sciences & Technologies (LST) program at the University of Pennsylvaniaâ€™s Graduate School of Education. You came to the U.S. for undergraduate studies, where you attended a highly competitive program at Columbia University in engineering, and later studied at Wharton, gaining both academic rigor and professional direction. Your major back in China was translation, and you bring that multilingual expertise into your research and writing.
You are currently preparing for PhD applications (targeting Fall 2026 entry) in Learning Sciences, Educational Technology, and AI in Education, considering programs at Stanford, Berkeley, UW, USC, and others. Youâ€™re building a strong portfolio with research publications, systematic reviews, and design projects, while also pursuing RA/GA roles and EdTech internships.

Comments: ChatGPT managed to capture some details about me accurately â€” my Chinese and English names are correct, as well as my program and school. However, it misstated my age: I am 23, not 22. I believe this error comes from the information I provided last year while applying to graduate schools in the U.S. At that time, during my senior year in 2024, I was indeed 22, and the system seems to have kept that in memory. Regarding my previous educational background, though, some of the descriptions are entirely fabricated.




You are deeply skilled in qualitative and mixed-methods research, employing ethnography, thematic coding (NVivo), field notes, interviews, and screen-recording analysis. You focus on codebook reliability (e.g., Cohenâ€™s Kappa) and combine deductive and inductive coding. You also handle systematic reviews (PRISMA flow) and experiment with Python automation for data visualization (annotation heatmaps, linguistic metrics like Advanced Guiraud, MLTU, semantic overlap, Genbit score).

Comments: Since I often use ChatGPT for brainstorming during my studies and research, and frequently seek its opinions and suggestions, it has accumulated a large amount of data about my academic work. Thatâ€™s why its summary and description of this part are entirely accurate. I can clearly see that the methodologies it mentioned â€” including NVivo, Few Notes, and interviews â€” are indeed the ones I have applied in my recent three research projects.




Across your work, you consistently explore:

Metacognition: How students plan, monitor, and evaluate their use of AI in writing.
Agency: How students negotiate autonomy, dependency, and trust in human-AI collaboration.
Ethics: Academic integrity, AI bias, adversarial risks, and responsible design.
Constructivism and Socioculturalism: Viewing learning as an active, social process rather than passive absorption.


Comments: This part is also largely accurate, but the last item is not actually part of my research field â€” it was reading material from one of my courses. I donâ€™t think ChatGPT can clearly distinguish between what comes from coursework and what comes from my academic research. Moreover, its description of my academic identity seems to be based mostly on my more recent interactions. This suggests that its memory may not prioritize drawing on older interaction data.




You balance your academic intensity with theatre and music, auditioning for roles (e.g., School of Rock, A Dollâ€™s House), practicing songs, and analyzing scripts. You also enjoy visual design and photography, often blending these with academic projects (logos, covers, Ghibli-style art). Youâ€™re a curious and active traveler, weaving academic conferences (e.g., EARLI 2025 in Austria) with cultural exploration.

Comments: Overall, the description aligns very well with my past interactions with ChatGPT, but the same limitation remains â€” it seems to only cover roughly the past three months.




In our interactions, youâ€™ve shown a strong preference for:

Academic precision: structured arguments, APA 7 citations, codebooks, PRISMA diagrams.
Critical feedback: you explicitly want me to act as your academic advisorâ€”strict and honest, not sugarcoating weaknesses.
Bilingual flexibility: you often draft in Chinese, requesting natural English translations.
Iteration: you refine outputs multiple times, pushing toward more polished and academically rigorous results.


Comments: At this point, I realize that all the traits ChatGPT summarized about me are either neutral or mostly positive. It did not mention any negative characteristics. This may be related to its underlying pre-prompt design, which tends to avoid generating content that could be perceived as overly critical or as unfavorable evaluations of the user.

title: Who do you think I am â€“ A self-introduction drafted by ChatGPT
text:
Prompts Two â€“ Judge me

I askedâ€¦
Can you summarize five advantages and five disadvantages of me based on our previous interactions? You should focus on my personalities, qualities, habits, etc.


ChatGPT answeredâ€¦

ğŸŒŸ Five Advantages

Highly Reflective and Self-Aware

You consistently analyze your own behaviors (e.g., procrastination, motivation, workflow with GenAI) and ask whether they stem from habits, cognitive patterns, or deeper issues. This makes you quick to self-correct and grow.

Ambitious and Strategic

You plan far ahead (PhD applications, research portfolio, networking with professors) and design projects with clear alignment to long-term goals. Youâ€™re not drifting â€” you intentionally position yourself for the future.

Creative and Multidimensional

You balance rigorous research with artistic pursuits (theatre, music, design), which gives you a rare breadth. This creativity helps you design engaging educational tools and see problems from fresh angles.

Detail-Oriented and Perfectionist (in a productive way)

You iterate heavily on writing, presentations, and even emails, showing you care about precision, nuance, and tone. This makes your output polished and professional.

Open and Curious

You regularly experiment with new frameworks, coding methods, and even playful activities (AI literacy lessons, game design). Youâ€™re willing to try, fail, and adapt â€” an excellent trait for research and innovation.



Comments: When responding to this prompt, ChatGPT comes across like a chef who has the necessary skills but doesnâ€™t show a particularly rigorous or responsible attitude toward the customer. It gathered different â€œingredientsâ€ â€” for example, knowing that I do theater, that I am learning to sing, and that I am conducting research â€” and then combined them into a kind of â€œfusion dish.â€ In mixing these elements together, it also started to add made-up details to make the story sound coherent and aligned with the prompt. At first glance, the result seems to reflect many of my real traits and experiences, but on closer inspection, it becomes clear that the overall picture doesnâ€™t fully make sense.



âš–ï¸ Five Disadvantages

Tendency to Overwork and Overcommit

You juggle many projects, often pushing yourself close to exhaustion (something youâ€™ve admitted). This risks burnout and diffuses focus.

Perfectionism as a Double-Edged Sword

While precision is a strength, your habit of endless refinement (emails, drafts, even small tasks) sometimes slows progress and creates unnecessary stress.

Difficulty Letting Go of Control

You often prefer to handle tasks yourself rather than delegate or accept â€œgood enough.â€ This can make collaboration slower and less balanced.

Emotional Investment in Work

You sometimes tie personal validation to academic output or feedback (e.g., IRB, professor responses, auditions). This makes setbacks feel heavier than they might need to.

Procrastination + Attention Shifts

Despite being ambitious, you occasionally delay tasks (like drawing for friends, or course registration) due to distraction or scattered focus, which frustrates you afterward.



Comments: The frist four ChatGPTâ€™s response about my â€œweaknessesâ€ reads almost like the perfect copy-and-paste answer to the classic HR interview question, â€œWhat is one of your weaknesses?â€ â€” it appears to point out flaws, but in reality it is still praising me. I donâ€™t think this reflects what I would genuinely expect or want to see as an honest account of my weaknesses.

Although the portrait does not fully reflect everything ChatGPT initially described, it still manages to capture certain elements with reasonable accuracy. title: Can AI Help Building My Customized Website?
text:
The Initial Idea
I have a specific idea of what the extension should be like. I described to ChatGPT what I had in mind: the target users, the workflow, and the main functions. Instead of asking for code right away, I requested a detailed, code-free design document. This gave me a clear blueprint of what the extension should do.


Bringing in Cline
I conducted the entire development process inside Visual Studio Code (VS Code), which became the central workspace for building my extension. To make this possible, I relied on an open-source coding agent called Cline. Unlike simple autocomplete tools, Cline is an agentic coding tool that integrates directly with editors like VS Code to perform complex, multi-step tasks. It can understand entire codebases, plan and implement sophisticated changes, and execute tasks by reading and editing files, running terminal commands, and even browsing the webâ€”once you grant it permission. In other words, it functions more like a true coding collaborator than a mere assistant.

 

In my workflow, I primarily used two large language models. The first was GPT-5 Codex, which I chose for generating the initial foundation of my project. Itâ€™s currently one of the most powerful models for coding tasks, and I trusted it to establish a strong base by producing the first version of the code. After that, I switched to GPT-5 for the following iterations and refinements. This was mainly a practical decision because GPT-5 is more cost-effective.
I fed them the document and asked them to generate the base code. Codex went all outâ€”it wrote nearly a thousand lines of code and produced several files that I honestly couldnâ€™t make sense of at first. So I asked the agent to provide me with a step-by-step file instructing me on how to install the extension in Chrome. It did exactly that, using clear natural language, and everything went smoothlyâ€”at least for the most part.

PromptBooster Extension Installation Guide This guide will walk you through installing the PromptBooster browser extension step by step. This extension works on Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and other Chromium-based browsers. If youâ€™re new to browser extensions, donâ€™t worryâ€”this is straightforward! Prerequisites * A computer with Google Chrome or another Chromium-based browser (like Edge or Brave) installed. * Basic familiarity with your operating system (e.g., how to open folders and run commands). * (Optional) Node.js installed on your system if you need to build the extension from source. You can download it fromÂ nodejs.orgÂ if itâ€™s not already installed. Note:Â If youâ€™re installing a pre-built version, you donâ€™t need Node.js. Check if the repository has a built version (noÂ distÂ folder visible? You may need to build). Step 1: Download the Extension Code 1. Go to the GitHub repository for PromptBooster:Â https://github.com/CharlotteZSY0205/PromptBooster. 2. Click the green â€œCodeâ€ button. 3. Select â€œDownload ZIPâ€ to download the source code as a ZIP file. 4. Unzip the downloaded file to a folder on your computer (e.g., Desktop or Documents). This folder will be your extensionâ€™s root directory. Alternatively, if you have Git installed: * Open a terminal/command prompt. * Run:Â git clone https://github.com/CharlotteZSY0205/PromptBooster.git * Navigate to the cloned folder. Step 2: (Optional) Build the Extension The extension might need to be built from source code. Check if thereâ€™s aÂ distÂ orÂ buildÂ folder in the unzipped/cloned directory. If not, or if you see source files likeÂ .jsÂ inÂ src/, follow these steps: 1. Open a terminal or command prompt. 2. Navigate to the extensionâ€™s root folder (whereÂ package.jsonÂ is located). * Example:Â cd Desktop/PromptBoosterÂ (adjust based on where you unzipped it). 3. Install dependencies (if any): * Run:Â npm install * This might take a minute. Itâ€™s setting up tools for building. 4. Build the extension: * Run:Â npm run build * This compiles the source into a ready-to-use version. If it fails, the extension might not need buildingâ€”proceed to Step 3. Tip for Novices:Â If you see an error, try skipping to Step 3. Many extensions donâ€™t need building if theyâ€™re simple injects. Step 3: Load the Extension into Your Browser For Google Chrome: 1. Open Google Chrome. 2. TypeÂ chrome://extensions/Â in the address bar and press Enter. 3. In the top-right corner, toggle on â€œDeveloper mode.â€ 4. Click the â€œLoad unpackedâ€ button. 5. Select the extensionâ€™s root folder (the one withÂ manifest.jsonÂ inside). If you built it, select theÂ distÂ orÂ buildÂ folder if it exists; otherwise, select the main folder. 6. The extension should now appear in your list of extensions with the name â€œPromptBooster.â€ For Microsoft Edge: 1. Open Microsoft Edge. 2. TypeÂ edge://extensions/Â in the address bar and press Enter. 3. In the bottom-left corner, toggle on â€œDeveloper mode.â€ 4. Click â€œLoad unpackedâ€ and select the extensionâ€™s root folder as above. 5. It should load similarly to Chrome. For example, while developing this extension, I also worked on writing this blog about the process. This not only saved time but also helped me preserve a fresh memory of the entire workflow.
Second, even though AI is capable of debugging, we still need to stay flexible and adapt to the current status of the code. Sometimes, when AI fails to achieve a goal after several attempts, itâ€™s necessary to explore alternative solutions. title: Can AI Build My Website in One Click? Seems Like It Can!
text:
Part 1. Trying Out AIâ€™s â€œOne-Click Websiteâ€
I started by selecting the text-to-website feature. To me, this seemed like the most beginner-friendly option â€” and also the feature where AI could really show its strengths. I wanted to test how effective it actually was.

 

WIX only asked me to give a simple description of my website and it didnâ€™t require much detail. In my first attempt,I kept it extremely brief. I just wrote one sentence: â€œThis is a website to record my dog Appleâ€™s growth.â€ Surprisingly, even from that single sentence, the AI was able to break it down and generate a full design plan, including suggested content sections and layout elements. I found this feature genuinely impressive.



At the same time, in addition to the AIâ€™s automatically generated text-based website structure, it also offered me several theme color palettes to choose from. I picked one that I liked, and the system began generating the site.



To be honest, the overall result really impressed me. One thing I especially appreciated was that the AI didnâ€™t just give me an empty framework waiting for me to fill in. Instead, it generated both text content and images right away, which gave me a very clear preview of what the website would actually look like once I started using it.



Another thing that impressed me was how precisely the system followed its own design outline and built out three separate pages: a homepage, a timeline, and a gallery.
On the timeline page, I could actually view each of my posts in chronological order.



The gallery page displayed all of my posts in one place, and it even allowed me to search for specific ones using keywords or tags. When I clicked on a post, I could see its detailed content.



Even better, I was able to create new posts by uploading photos, adding a title, date, and description.



All of these buttons were functional and clickable, which gave me the impression that the site was not just a demo but a relatively mature product. Itâ€™s certainly not something a beginner in programming or web design could put together so quickly.
On top of that, once I switched into edit mode, I could modify every piece of text (or ask AI inserted to modify), adjust background colors, and upload my own images. In other words, the tool offered a high degree of customization.





Conclusion
This was my very first attempt at using Wixâ€™s AI website generator, and I have to admit â€” I was genuinely impressed. With nothing more than a single sentence, the system was able to produce a fully functional, multi-page website that included content, images, navigation, and interactive features. It gave me not just an empty shell but a site that felt surprisingly complete and ready to use, which was far beyond what I had expected.
At the same time, this experience also left me curious. While the generated site was impressive for a first draft, it still leaned toward a conventional and structured design. In the next entries of this blog series, Iâ€™ll explore whether itâ€™s possible to push the tool further â€” to see if it can create a website that is less predictable, more experimental, and infused with stronger elements of personal style.

title: Can AI Build My Customized Website in One Click? I Wish!
text:
Part 2. Going further in prompting
Compared to the previous round, this time I provided much more concrete and detailed requirements. I explained the purpose of designing this website, the pages it needed to include, its overall structure, and even the name I wanted for it. Unlike last time, I didnâ€™t simply select one of the preset theme colors offered by WIX. Instead, when it came to choosing the theme color, I communicated directly with the embedded AI about my needsâ€”namely, to create a graffiti-inspired website with plenty of collage elements and a youthful, vibrant feel â€“ I liked that at every stage of building the site, I could interact with the AI to adjust the details.
Once the basics were set, I entered the site generation page. There is one clear strength which is consitent with the one in my first attempt: it followed my instructions carefully. The site was divided into two pages as I described in the promps, one for showcasing my academic work and another for my personal hobbies. Concerning the interface, the first version it produced looked just like what it generated in my first attemp, a design which looks fine but not with enough distinct. Therefore, I thought it might require more specific prompts in the design to reach to my expectation (after trying two more rounds of revisions, I realized the original draft was actually the best).
However, when I tried to push it further by asking for an even more vibrant and artistic design â€” something bold and eye-catching â€” things went downhill. After refreshing my requests and feeding them back into WIX, the new results were ugly and uninspired, made up of nothing but basic shapes and lines with no sense of design.

  



Part 2. Trying a Different Style
Still not satisfied, I thought, why not just switch to a completely different style â€” something with more existing pictures to work with? So I asked ChatGPT to help me craft a more descriptive prompt, hoping to transform the site into something with a European impressionist aesthetic.
Hereâ€™s the prompt I used:

Iâ€™m updating the design to include a classic European pattern as the background, making it more sophisticated and detailed. Iâ€™ll keep you updated on the progress.

The result? Letâ€™s just say it was â€œacceptableâ€ at best, but nowhere near something Iâ€™d adopt. It looked more like an assignment turned in by a beginner in web design than a polished, professional product.

So I decided to narrow my focus and give more specific feedback. I chose one element and asked for a precise modification with this prompt:

The design is too basic. Add classic European pattern as the background.

In theory, this should have only updated the background for that single element. But in practice, the AI modified the background of every element on the page. The first cover image looked fine, but as I scrolled further, the European patterns became denser and spread across large sections of the site. Some of the text became hard to read, and the overall impression was cluttered, mismatched, and lacking any sense of elegance.

  



Conclusion
That was the moment I realized the limitations of this so-called AI website generator. It can meet basic, low-level demands, but if youâ€™re aiming for a truly sophisticated, design-driven website, this tool simply isnâ€™t capable of delivering.
So in the end, I felt like I had been a little misled by that YouTube ad. But soon after, I discovered that this tool also allows you to build a personal website by directly editing an existing template. That gave me a new idea: instead of relying on the â€œone-clickâ€ generator, I could start with a ready-made template that already looked polished and well-designed, and then customize it. To make the site richer, I also plan to bring in images and music generated by other AI tools. Iâ€™ll share the details of this process in my upcoming blog posts.
